title: How I Grow Tomatoes Indoors
description: Start with high-quality seeds, use a deep container, and ensure at least 6 hours of sunlight. Water regularly and use organic fertilizer for best results.

title: Balcony Composting Made Easy
description: Use a small bin with a tight lid, add kitchen scraps and dry leaves, and turn the pile weekly. In 2-3 months, you'll have rich compost for your plants.

title: Hydroponics for Beginners
description: Set up a simple hydroponic system using a plastic tub, net pots, and nutrient solution. Monitor pH and light for optimal growth.

title: Vertical Gardening in Small Spaces
description: Use wall-mounted planters or recycled bottles to grow herbs vertically. Ensure good drainage and sunlight for healthy plants.

title: Caring for Succulents
description: Place succulents in bright, indirect light and water only when the soil is dry. Use a well-draining mix to prevent root rot.

title: DIY Drip Irrigation System
description: Use recycled bottles or a hose with small holes to create a simple drip irrigation system. This saves water and keeps plants healthy.

title: Growing Basil on a Windowsill
description: Use a small pot with drainage, place it on a sunny windowsill, and water when the soil feels dry. Pinch off flowers to encourage more leaf growth.

title: Making a DIY Self-Watering Planter
description: Repurpose a plastic bottle to create a self-watering system. Cut the bottle in half, invert the top, and use a cotton string as a wick. Fill the bottom with water and let the plant absorb moisture as needed.

title: Quick Guide to Balcony Herb Gardens
description: Choose compact herb varieties, use lightweight containers, and ensure at least 4 hours of sunlight. Rotate pots weekly for even growth.

title: How to Propagate Snake Plants
description: Cut a healthy leaf into sections, let them dry for a day, and plant in moist soil. Keep in indirect light and water sparingly until roots develop.

title: Composting Kitchen Scraps in Small Spaces
description: Use a small lidded container for kitchen scraps. Add dry leaves or shredded paper to balance moisture and reduce odor. Stir weekly for faster decomposition.
